hard_x_rays/channel.documentation: Set of channels (detector or pixel of a camera)

hard_x_rays/channel/name.documentation: Short string identifier (unique for a given device)

hard_x_rays/channel/description.documentation: Description, e.g. “channel viewing the upper divertor”

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/geometry_ty.documentation: Type of geometry used to describe the surface of the detector or aperture (1:'outline', 2:'circular', 3:'rectangle'). In case of 'outline', the surface is described by an outline of point in a local coordinate system defined by a centre and three unit vectors X1, X2, X3. Note that there is some flexibility here and the data provider should choose the most convenient coordinate system for the object, respecting the definitions of (X1,X2,X3) indicated below. In case of 'circular', the surface is a circle defined by its centre, radius, and normal vector oriented towards the plasma X3.  In case of 'rectangle', the surface is a rectangle defined by its centre, widths in the X1 and X2 directions, and normal vector oriented towards the plasma X3.

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/centre.documentation: If geometry_type=2, coordinates of the centre of the circle. If geometry_type=1 or 3, coordinates of the origin of the local coordinate system (X1,X2,X3) describing the plane detector/aperture. This origin is located within the detector/aperture area.

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/centre/phi.documentation: Toroidal angle (oriented counter-clockwise when viewing from above)

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/radius.documentation: Radius of the circle, used only if geometry_type = 2

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/x1_unit_vec.documentation: Components of the X1 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X1 vector is more horizontal than X2 (has a smaller abs(Z) component) and oriented in the positive phi direction (counter-clockwise when viewing from above).

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/x2_unit_vec.documentation: Components of the X2 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X2 axis is orthonormal so that uX2 = uX3 x uX1.

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/x3_unit_vec.documentation: Components of the X3 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X3 axis is normal to the detector/aperture plane and oriented towards the plasma.

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/x1_width.documentation: Full width of the aperture in the X1 direction, used only if geometry_type = 3

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/x2_width.documentation: Full width of the aperture in the X2 direction, used only if geometry_type = 3

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/outline.documentation: Irregular outline of the detector/aperture in the (X1, X2) coordinate system. Repeat the first point since this is a closed contour

hard_x_rays/channel/detector/surface.documentation: Surface of the detector/aperture, derived from the above geometric data

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture.documentation: Description of a set of collimating apertures

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/geometry_ty.documentation: Type of geometry used to describe the surface of the detector or aperture (1:'outline', 2:'circular', 3:'rectangle'). In case of 'outline', the surface is described by an outline of point in a local coordinate system defined by a centre and three unit vectors X1, X2, X3. Note that there is some flexibility here and the data provider should choose the most convenient coordinate system for the object, respecting the definitions of (X1,X2,X3) indicated below. In case of 'circular', the surface is a circle defined by its centre, radius, and normal vector oriented towards the plasma X3.  In case of 'rectangle', the surface is a rectangle defined by its centre, widths in the X1 and X2 directions, and normal vector oriented towards the plasma X3.

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/centre.documentation: If geometry_type=2, coordinates of the centre of the circle. If geometry_type=1 or 3, coordinates of the origin of the local coordinate system (X1,X2,X3) describing the plane detector/aperture. This origin is located within the detector/aperture area.

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/centre/phi.documentation: Toroidal angle (oriented counter-clockwise when viewing from above)

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/radius.documentation: Radius of the circle, used only if geometry_type = 2

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/x1_unit_vec.documentation: Components of the X1 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X1 vector is more horizontal than X2 (has a smaller abs(Z) component) and oriented in the positive phi direction (counter-clockwise when viewing from above).

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/x2_unit_vec.documentation: Components of the X2 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X2 axis is orthonormal so that uX2 = uX3 x uX1.

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/x3_unit_vec.documentation: Components of the X3 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X3 axis is normal to the detector/aperture plane and oriented towards the plasma.

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/x1_width.documentation: Full width of the aperture in the X1 direction, used only if geometry_type = 3

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/x2_width.documentation: Full width of the aperture in the X2 direction, used only if geometry_type = 3

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/outline.documentation: Irregular outline of the detector/aperture in the (X1, X2) coordinate system. Repeat the first point since this is a closed contour

hard_x_rays/channel/aperture/surface.documentation: Surface of the detector/aperture, derived from the above geometric data

hard_x_rays/channel/etendue.documentation: Etendue (geometric extent) of the channel's optical system

hard_x_rays/channel/etendue_method.documentation: Method used to calculate the etendue. Index = 0 : exact calculation with a 4D integral; 1 : approximation with first order formula (detector surface times solid angle subtended by the apertures); 2 : other methods

hard_x_rays/channel/etendue_method/index.documentation: Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.

hard_x_rays/channel/line_of_sight.documentation: Description of the line of sight of the channel, given by 2 points

hard_x_rays/channel/line_of_sight/first_.documentation: Toroidal angle (oriented counter-clockwise when viewing from above)

hard_x_rays/channel/line_of_sight/second.documentation: Toroidal angle (oriented counter-clockwise when viewing from above)

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/name.documentation: Short string identifier (unique for a given device)

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/descri.documentation: Description, e.g. “channel viewing the upper divertor”

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/geomet.documentation: Geometry of the filter contour. Note that there is some flexibility in the choice of the local coordinate system (X1,X2,X3). The data provider should choose the most convenient coordinate system for the filter, respecting the definitions of (X1,X2,X3) indicated below.
Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/curvat.documentation: Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/centre.documentation: Coordinates of the origin of the local coordinate system (X1,X2,X3) describing the filter. This origin is located within the filter area and should be the middle point of the filter surface. If geometry_type=2, it's the centre of the circular filter. If geometry_type=3, it's the centre of the rectangular filter.
Toroidal angle (oriented counter-clockwise when viewing from above)

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/radius.documentation: Radius of the circle, used only if geometry_type/index = 2

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/x1_uni.documentation: Components of the X1 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X1 vector is more horizontal than X2 (has a smaller abs(Z) component) and oriented in the positive phi direction (counter-clockwise when viewing from above).

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/x2_uni.documentation: Components of the X2 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X2 axis is orthonormal so that uX2 = uX3 x uX1.

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/x3_uni.documentation: Components of the X3 direction unit vector in the (X,Y,Z) coordinate system, where X is the major radius axis for phi = 0, Y is the major radius axis for phi = pi/2, and Z is the height axis. The X3 axis is normal to the filter surface and oriented towards the plasma.

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/x1_wid.documentation: Full width of the filter in the X1 direction, used only if geometry_type/index = 3

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/x2_wid.documentation: Full width of the filter in the X2 direction, used only if geometry_type/index = 3

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/outlin.documentation: Irregular outline of the filter in the (X1, X2) coordinate system, used only if geometry_type/index=1. Repeat the first point since this is a closed contour

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/x1_cur.documentation: Radius of curvature in the X1 direction, to be filled only for curvature_type/index = 2, 4 or 5

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/x2_cur.documentation: Radius of curvature in the X2 direction, to be filled only for curvature_type/index = 3 or 5

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/surfac.documentation: Surface of the filter, derived from the above geometric data

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/materi.documentation: Integer identifier (enumeration index within a list). Private identifier values must be indicated by a negative index.

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/wavele.documentation: Lower bound of the filter wavelength range
Upper bound of the filter wavelength range

hard_x_rays/channel/filter_window/photon.documentation: Probability of absorbing a photon passing through the filter as a function of its wavelength

hard_x_rays/channel/energy_band.documentation: Set of energy bands in which photons are counted by the detector

hard_x_rays/channel/energy_band/lower_bo.documentation: Lower bound of the energy band

hard_x_rays/channel/energy_band/upper_bo.documentation: Upper bound of the energy band

hard_x_rays/channel/energy_band/energies.documentation: Array of discrete energy values inside the band

hard_x_rays/channel/energy_band/detectio.documentation: Probability of detection of a photon impacting the detector as a function of its energy

hard_x_rays/channel/radiance.documentation: Photons received by the detector per unit time, per unit solid angle and per unit area (i.e. photon flux divided by the etendue), in multiple energy bands if available from the detector

hard_x_rays/channel/radiance/validity_ti.documentation: Indicator of the validity of the data for each time slice. 0: valid from automated processing, 1: valid and certified by the diagnostic RO; - 1 means problem identified in the data processing (request verification by the diagnostic RO), -2: invalid data, should not be used (values lower than -2 have a code-specific meaning detailing the origin of their invalidity)

hard_x_rays/channel/radiance/validity.documentation: Indicator of the validity of the data for the whole acquisition period. 0: valid from automated processing, 1: valid and certified by the diagnostic RO; - 1 means problem identified in the data processing (request verification by the diagnostic RO), -2: invalid data, should not be used (values lower than -2 have a code-specific meaning detailing the origin of their invalidity)

hard_x_rays/emissivity_profile_1d.documentation: Emissivity profile per energy band (assumed common to all channels used in the profile reconstruction)

hard_x_rays/emissivity_profile_1d/lower_.documentation: Lower bound of the energy band

hard_x_rays/emissivity_profile_1d/upper_.documentation: Upper bound of the energy band

hard_x_rays/emissivity_profile_1d/emissi.documentation: Radial profile of the plasma emissivity in this energy band

hard_x_rays/emissivity_profile_1d/peak_p.documentation: Normalized toroidal flux coordinate position at which the emissivity peaks

hard_x_rays/emissivity_profile_1d/half_w.documentation: Internal (towards magnetic axis) half width of the emissivity peak (in normalized toroidal flux)
External (towards separatrix) half width of the emissivity peak (in normalized toroidal flux)

hard_x_rays/emissivity_profile_1d/validi.documentation: Indicator of the validity of the emissivity profile data for each time slice. 0: valid from automated processing, 1: valid and certified by the diagnostic RO; - 1 means problem identified in the data processing (request verification by the diagnostic RO), -2: invalid data, should not be used (values lower than -2 have a code-specific meaning detailing the origin of their invalidity)

hard_x_rays/latency.documentation: Upper bound of the delay between physical information received by the detector and data available on the real-time (RT) network.
